results.title: Rogerstone
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and Northern Aluminium Company
results.brief_description: A survey of the continuous aluminium strip rolling mill at Rogerstone, where modern machinery, mechanical handling and efficient factory layout enable single ingots of aluminium to be rolled in continuous lengths of as much as 3,500 feet. The opening of this mill in 1950 increased Britain’s aluminium sheet rolling capacity by one-third.
results.description: A survey of the continuous aluminium strip rolling mill at Rogerstone, where modern machinery, mechanical handling and efficient factory layout enable single ingots of aluminium to be rolled in continuous lengths of as much as 3,500 feet. results.title: Rocks and minerals: how do we identify them?
results.creator_credit: Tom Ascher and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Noticing the pattern, composition and texture of rocks we find that we can identify them, and gain clues how they are formed. Minerals are identified by tests which can lead to an understanding of processes occurring within the earth.

results.title: Rocks and minerals
results.brief_description: Describes the three classes of rocks - igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic - and relates them to the natural conditions that produced them. Explains the varied uses of rocks and minerals in their natural state, including basalt, pumice, granite, limestone, sandstone, marble and others.

results.title: Rocket range Australia
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, Shan Benson, Australian National Film Board and Dept of the Interior
results.brief_description: The Weapons Research Establishment at Salisbury and Woomera, South Australia. Shows the Salisbury Headquarters with its workshops, scientific testing of equipment, and wind tunnel. Also life in Woomera township and weapons research on the rocket range, including the engagement of a Jindivick pilotless aircraft by a Fireflash air-to-air missile and the launching of a skylark ground-to-air rocket.

results.title: Rock engravings
results.brief_description: Aboriginal rock carvings in Western New South Wales are being studied by archaeologists to discover their significance and to throw light on the culture which produced them. The age of the carvings cannot be determined, but many may be thousands of years old.
results.description: Aboriginal rock carvings in Western New South Wales are being studied by archaeologists to discover their significance and to throw light on the culture which produced them. The age of the carvings cannot be determined, but many may be thousands of years old.

results.title: Rock bottom at Waikaremoana
results.brief_description: The lake at Waikaremoana is one of the North Island’s major sources of water for hydro-electric power. However, weakness in the bed of the lake has resulted in considerable loss of valuable water. With a full-sized movie camera fitted in his special diving helmet, a cameraman recorded how divers located and sealed these leaks in the lake bed.
